I am submitting this request under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.  I believe this request to be of reasonable nature as it does not ask for you to disclose commercially sensitive information or trade secrets. Should this not be the case, please let me know and I will re-frame the request.   My request is that the your Authority provides me with the following information relating to the services provided by the Authority or Third party suppliers via an Authority contract broken down by school which are under the Authority's control. Specifically, the contracts relate to the following provision types (where outsourced and not internally provided by a school): -          Cleaning-          Catering I would like to receive the following information broken down by school in electronic format;-          The supplier who provides the service (if the services are provided by a third party supplier and not directly by the Authority)-          The start and end dates of each school contract-          The yearly value of each school contract

An answer to a previous FOI submission made by another party showed that DCC had received 12 offers of interest from private operations interested in buying or acquiring some of the council-owned care homes threatened with closure. I would like to request copies of any correspondence the council entered into regarding these approaches. If no written correspondence was received, what were those expressing an interest told re: possible sale or transfer of the homes? Of the 12 approaches which were made, where it was specified, I request details of which homes were inquired about, were expressions made about specific homes or about a group of homes with certain areas. Please confirm if any homes in Mid Devon (e.g. Charlton Lodge, Barnhaven, Orchard Lea and St Lawrence) were subject of an enquiry from the private sector. Could I also request an update as to whether the council has received any further enquires about take-over/sale or one or any of its care homes since the previous figures leading up to July 2014 were provided? If I can provide any further information to assist with the timely completion of my request,

I would like to receive the following: -          Your selection criteria for Part P and renewables installers on all tendering and contract based selection exercises (inclusive of Housing, Leisure & Culture, Health & Social, Education, Highways, Repair & Maintenance, Environmental Health, Building Control & Renewable Energy departments).-          Details on the process for obtaining approved status for Part P and renewables installers who are certified under Stroma Certification's Competent Person Schemes. Stroma Certification is a DCLG approved certification body for installers and assessors. Our Competent Person Schemes, Microgeneration Certification Schemes, and Green Deal Assessor Organisation and Green Deal Installer certification schemes are all UKAS-accredited to ISO/IEC 17065: 2012. Certain competitor organisations of ours are already on the approved lists (e.g. NAPIT and NICEIC) and we are seeking equal recognition for Stroma-certified members going through public sector contract and tendering processes.

The number of schools in your council area which will/are expected to be providing hot universal infant free school meals by January 2015.6.	The number of schools in your council area which will/are expected to be providing cold universal infant free school meals (no hot meals) by January 2015.7.	The number of schools in your council area which will NOT/are NOT expected to be providing universal infant free school meals by January 2015.

In the interest of clarity, when I refer to Direct Payment recipients, I refer specifically to adults and children (and their families) in receipt of a Direct Payment from the council to meet their assessed care needs.  Furthermore my request refers specifically to people using their Direct Payment from the council to employ their own carer/personal assistant(s).  I will refer to this group as Direct Payment (DP) employers.DP employers are required by law to purchase employers liability insurance which is (in most cases) funded by the council.To answer this FOI request, please could you provide the following information;1. Does the council currently provide funding for DP employers to cover employers liability insurance?2. If yes, please could you confirm if the money, allocated to each DP employer to cover their insurance     requirements is capped or limited to a certain amount?3. If this figure is capped or limited please could you confirm the maximum allocation provided by the council?4. If a DP employer chooses to spend more than the allocated or capped amount, can they choose to top this up with their own money and purchase a more expensive policy?5. Is the local authority currently contracted to an insurance provider to cover the insurance needs of its DP employers?

Please provide the following information that your local authority holds as of 1 July 2014:1. How many looked after children are in the care of your local authority as of 1 July 2014?2.a) How many sibling groups are in the care of your local authority as of 1 July 2014?b) Of these, how many are sibling groups comprising:i.        2 childrenii.      3 childreniii.    4 childreniv.     More than 4 children?3.a) How many sibling groups are all placed together?b) Of these, how many are:     i. in unrelated foster care     ii. in kinship foster care     iii. in residential care     iv placed for adoption? 4.a) How many children in your care, who are part of a sibling group, are not living with at least one of their siblings?b) Of these how many are:     i. in unrelated foster care     ii. in kinship foster care     iii. in residential care     iv placed for adoption?5.a) Please state the number of looked after children in your care being raised by a connected person.b) Of these how many are fostered by an older sibling?6. Please provide any current local policies and guidance on the placement of siblings within the looked after system.

1. Please forward me a complete copy of DCC's policy statement on the use of covert surveillance under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act [RIPA]. [I stress this is a request for policy only, I am not asking for tactical guidance or details of protected methodology.]2. Which DCC Officers, if any, have the authority to grant the use of Covert surveillance under RIPA? 3. Have the provisions of the Protection of Freedoms Act 2012 been affected within the authority?4. Directed surveillance crime threshold. Have the amendments to the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (Directed Surveillance and Covert Human Intelligence Sources) Order 2010 been affected within the authority? How is this monitored?5. What training is provided to relevant staff to differentiate between Directed surveillance and casual observation? How is this knowledge tested?6. When did the Surveillance Commissioner last inspect DCC's use of RIPA? Can you let me have a copy of the Commissioners Report?7. Since the introduction of RIPA, how many requests were authorised year by year relating to surveillance of residents' disposal of waste?8. Since the introduction of RIPA, how many requests were authorised year by year relating to surveillance of businesses' disposal of waste?9. Since the introduction of RIPA, how many requests were authorised year by year relating to surveillance of persons "fly-tipping"?10. Of the authorisations that were granted, how many requests were considered to be 'collateral intrusion', having impacted on the privacy of a third party not under investigation?11. What systems, processes and/or policies do you have in place to prevent, restrict or mitigate "collateral intrusion"?

1.....Does the council have responsibility for libraries and or other book lending services within its area?  2.....If the answer is yes can you please state how many copies of each of the following books are held by the libraries and other book lending services within your area.     All three books are by the same author E L James.      Please include all copies irrespective of whether they are currently on loan or not.  Please do include all hard back copies, paper back copies, audio books and or large print editions.   Fifty Shades of Grey.Fifty Shades DarkerFifty Shades Freed  3....In the case of each of the aforementioned books can you say how many individual public loans have so far been generated by libraries and other book lending services within year area?   Please provide an overall figure for each title.   4...In the case of each title and in the case of each library within your area can you please state whether there is a waiting list for the book.  In the case of each book and library can you state how long that waiting list is.  5....Does the library service hold copies of correspondence and or communications with individual library users and or members of the public which in any way relates to the trilogy and or the individual books within the series.    If the answer is yes can you please provide copies of that correspondence and communications including emails?       Please note that I am only interested in correspondence which has been generated since 1 January 2013  to the present day.   In the case of each piece of correspondence please feel free to redact the name and address of any correspondent or member of library staff.  6...Since 1 January 2013 has the library service exchanged correspondence and communications with Vintage Books and or Random House which publishes the titles.  I am only interested in correspondence and communications which in any way relates to the issue of the books being offered for loan.  If the answer is yes can you please provide copies of this correspondence and communications including emails.

The Men's Health Forum is currently researching invitation, referral and response rates to NHS Health Checks by gender. To this end, please can you answer the following questions about NHS Health Checks in your local authority area:1.	In 2013/14, how many men and how many women in your area: o	were eligible for NHS Health Checks?o	were offered a NHS Health Check?o	received a NHS Health Check?2.	What analysis have you done to identify higher risk groups of men or men who are less likely to take up the offer of a health check (e.g. by age, ethnicity, deprivation)?3.	What initiatives, if any, have you taken or are you planning to increase uptake, referrals or follow up amongst men - especially higher risk groups of men?4.	Have you undertaken a Health Equity Audit? If so, is it possible to be sent a copy?5.	Does your JSNA address equity related to NHS Health Check risk assessment and provision and uptake of lifestyle and clinical services?

I would like to request information relating to your authority's plans and decisions made around cloud hosting of your corporate website, or any other sites owned, developed or maintained by the Council over the last three years. In particular I would like to know:1.	Whether you currently use cloud-based servers to host any of your public facing websites2.	If yes, what were the reasons for/against the decision to use cloud-based hosting3.	If yes, how much does each website cost and how much money (if any) are you saving by using cloud-based hosting4.	If no, whether you have considered using cloud-based hosting and what your reasons for/against the decision wereI should prefer to receive these in electronic format at this email address, however, I am happy to receive them by post if that is more convenient.It would be helpful if you were to provide any brief notes which might be necessary to understand the context of the information provided, although I recognise that you are not obliged to do this. If for any reason you feel this request is unclear, please do not hesitate to contact me at 07739 089 846. If you are not the appropriate authority for this request, or for part of it, please let me know as soon as is convenient.

I had a Highway Incident Report Form (Claimant) returned to me recently because, ratherthan include proof of a valid tax disc with my documents, I had referred you to theGovernment's website - vehicleenquiry.service.gov.uk. I strongly believe that checking asmuch information as possible online has to make economic sense for both the Claimant andthe Council; the Government's vehicle tax disc renewal site checks for insurance and MOTby these means.As a consequence, I wish to make a Freedom of Information request for the followinginformation -1. How many claim forms have been returned to claimants in the last 5 years becauserequested copy documentation had not been included? Please group results bydocument name, eg proof of tax, proof of insurance2. How many claims have been ultimately unsuccessful purely on the basis ofinadequate copy documentation, again grouped by document type3. It is not at all obvious why some documentation has been requested, since theabsence of such documentary proof, in my opinion, would be unlikely to impact on aclaim for damage. Canyou please provide details of the process by which these copydocuments were selected for inclusion in the Highway Incident Report Form(Claimant) and by what authority they are issued in the Council's name

column3: Highways Capital Development and Waste Management
column7: My name is Jack Donativo and I am a Bsc (Hons) Policing and Criminal Investigation student at Staffordshire University. I am about to start my final year research project in to the effectiveness of street lighting on crime. Part of my research includes how effective street lighting can be as a tool against crime throughout different times of day and which crimes it affects most. Under The Freedom Of Information Act 2000 I would like to request some pieces of information from you. 1). The times that street lighting is on throughout the year for the last 10 years. 2). The number of recorded crimes for the area where there is street lighting for the last 10 years. I'm not investigating the exact crime but whether it is serious or volume crime, but any form of information on this I can process myself.

column3: Highways Capital Development and Waste Management
column7: I am writing to inform you that I have been given a PCN in error.I arrived at Exmouth seafront in order to do some buying of antiques from a fair held atthe Exmoor Pavilion. I was fortunate enough to get a parking space very near thevenue, especially as the weather was particularly stormy with high winds and showers.I was also fortunate to be able to park near the Pay-and-display machine (413) but soonfound out that it was faulty because it was not accepting any coins but displayed no outof order notice on its led screen. I walked up to the nearest machine from it (412) andproceeded to put my coins in - this was at 11AOam. I remember clearly putting in onepound coin and the rest in silver (3 x 20p and 4 x lOp) for two hours - the led displayshowed an expiry time of 13AOhrs which was more than enough time for me. Idisplayed my ticket and went to the pavilion. I was surprised when I discovered uponreturning to my car (around 13.lOhrs) that there was a parking ticket stuck to thewindow. Upon checking why this was the case, it confirmed that the ticket issued wasonly for one hour.It is obvious that your machine is faulty and printed the wrong time.Because of this I am requesting the following under the Freedom of Information2000:I would like an engineers report confirming the date and time ofthe last service and recallibrationof machine 412I would like to see a printout of the said machine for 11040 of what coins it accepted /rejected (if any)I would like a copy of a current engineers report confirming that machine 412 isworking within the manufacturers specificationsI would like copies of any complaints received by the council regarding faulty ticketmachines in this area from people who have been wrongly accused of defaulting ontheir ticket.The fact that I purchased a ticket in the first place proves I had no intention of default,the ticket itself does not contain any terms or conditions by the ticket issuer, which, asit is a receipt for a financial transaction, it should do.The current government has expressed a desire that all unnecessary parking fines bequashed as (a) it does not represent a fair fee for non-compliance, (b) it affects tourismin a depressed economic time by antagonising the visitor into not returning in thefuture, (c) does not give the recipient a reasonable recourse to complain underTHREAT of doubling the charge.

I have tried to phone you a couple of times but have been unable to reach you.  I am grateful for your letter of 11th June but I have not been in the emotional space to respond.  With Joan Mitchell moving to a nursing home yesterday, and my gradual recovery from Patsy's death, I now feel in a position to follow up the Safeguarding referral. I am not sure if the final report has yet been completed, but I would like to make a formal request to receive a copy.  If it is necessary to invoke the Freedom of Information legislation, I hereby do so. I appreciate that parts of the report (e.g. relating to individual staff members or residents) may be confidential, but I would be happy to receive the report with those sections omitted or blanked out. I appreciate that I am not a blood relative of Joan Mitchell.  However, I actively supported my wife through the agonising process of trying to get Safeguarding to take her concerns seriously, and I am one of her two executors, so I feel that I am a party to the issue and feel that I am entitled to be satisfied that Patsy's concerns have been comprehensively dealt with and the appropriate actions taken.  If legally required, I can ask one of my three adult children (i.e. Joan's grandchildren) to make the formal request. I look forward to hearing from you at your earliest convenience.

column7: Homecare 1 - Does your council commission homecare visits of 15 minutes (or less)?2- What proportion of your homecare visits are 15 minutes (or less)?3- What proportion of your 15 minute (or less) visits include the delivery of any personal care*?4 - Do you make it contractual condition that your homecare providers pay their care workers for their travel time?Residential care for older people5 - What is the fee, or range of fees, that your authority currently pays for a) a week of residential care? b) a week of nursing care? 6 - Compared with last 12 months ago have the fees that you pay providers for a) residential care b) nursing care1.	increased 2.	stayed the same3.	decreased?7 - Do you include as a contractual condition for your residential and nursing care providers minimum staffing levels in their homes overnight?Residential and homecare8 - What percentage profit margin for providers do you assume in your contract costing modelling?  (for both homecare and residential care)9 - Do you make payment of the National Minimum Wage a contract condition for your homecare and residential care services?10 - Have you ever asked to see pay records and/or other documentary evidence about the pay of care workers employed by care providers you commission in order to check National Minimum Wage compliance?  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------* Personal care is defined by Care Standards Act 2000 as1.	Assistance with bodily functions such as feeding, bathing and toileting2.	Care falling just short of assistance with bodily functions, but still involving physical and intimate touching, including activities such as helping a person get out of a bath and helping them to get dressed.3.	Non-physical care, such as advice, encouragement and supervision relating to the foregoing, such as prompting a person to take a bath and supervising them during this.4.	Emotional and psychological support, including the promotion of social functioning, behaviour management, and assistance with cognitive functions.

column7: Could you please send me the following information about housing benefit claimants who are on variable or fluctuating incomes and must submit regular payslips and wage information to the council for housing benefit claim adjustments.Could you let me know:- How many housing benefit recipients does your council have in total?- Out of that total, how many are in receipt of housing benefit and how many are in receipt of local housing allowance (LHA)?- How many households claiming housing benefit through your council have a variable or fluctuating income and must submit payslips and wage information for housing benefit adjustments on a regular basis because their income varies?- How does the council calculate housing benefit claims for people on variable or fluctuating incomes - for example, does the council calculate a monthly income average, or a weekly income average?- How regularly must people on variable or fluctuating incomes submit their payslips and wage information for housing benefit adjustment?- What formats can people use to report variable or fluctuating incomes and to submit payslips or wage information? Do they have to hand-deliver or post payslips and wage information through the mail, or are they able to submit information electronically?- If so, what systems can people use to make those submissions (for example - can they email information, use online forms, etc). Is online reporting possible?- How long do housing benefit claims that are adjusted to accommodate variable incomes take to process?

I am undertaking some research on journal controls in local government and I would be very grateful if you could provide answers to the following questions;1. Does your finance department require authorisation of accounting journals prior to entry i.e. does the journal need to be approved by another person before it can be processed ?2. If the answer to 1. is 'No' - is there any post entry authorisation of journals ?3. Does your finance department allow accounting journals to be entered remotely from outside the office i.e. when finance staff are working from home/outside the office.4. If the answer to 3. is 'Yes' - have your internal or external audit functions ever raised concerns about these 'remote journals' and where they serious or moderate or low risk concerns. Where these concerns ever mentioned on your Annual audit letters5. If the answer to 4 is 'Yes' - do you intend to do anything about it6. If the answer to 4 is 'Yes' - what did you understand audits concerns to be about i.e. were they concerned about hacking risks or risks of journals not being authorised before being processed or something else.7. Finally - in the opinion of your chief accountant or Financial services manager or chief internal auditor  - how much ADDITIONAL risk is created to the council on a scale of 1 to 10 (where 10 is high 'added risk') of allowing journals to be entered remotely (e.g.staff  working from home) when there is ALREADY NO pre-authorisation procedure in place for ALL JOURNALS (done remotely or in the office) - i.e. where all journals entered are automatically consolidated to the finance system with no pre-authorisation process. I know it is subjective but any estimation of additional risk is much appreciated.

Hi,Please provide the following information under the freedom of information act:"How much has your authority spent on private transportation for people to get to school in the years of 2012 and 2013?""Private transportation" being defined as any vehicle hired from a private firm which isn't within the subsidised bus transport readily available to most school pupils.Please provide a breakdown of how much each trip cost and date.

I am carrying out some research and accordingly request the following under the Freedom of Information Act: 1.     Since 1 January 2013, has any software company exercised their contractual rights to, or otherwise requested, an audit of the use of their software in your organisation? 2.     Was the request made in 2013 or 2014? 3.     Did they use an external consultant or license management company to carry out such audit? If so, which company:a.     License Management Servicesb.    Other (please specify) 4.     Did the audit result in a demand in respect of:a.     Under-licensing; and/orb.    Arrears of support and maintenance? 5.     Did your organisation negotiate with the software vendor to reduce the figure? 6.     If so, what %ge reduction was obtained from the vendor's first demand:a.     Noneb.    1-10%;c.     11-25%d.    26-50%e.     More than 50%? 7.     If any payment was made to regularise the situation, was the amount:a.     Zerob.    Less than £50,000c.     £50,000 to £100,000d.    £100,00 to £250,000e.     £250,000 to £500,000f.     £500,000 to £1m;g.    £1m to £2m;h.     £2m to £5mi.      Above £5m? 8.     Was the software vendor involved:a.     Oracleb.    SAPc.     SASd.    PeopleSoft;e.     IBMf.     Microsoft;g.    Sybaseh.     Adobei.      Other? (please specify) 9.     In dealing with the software vendor, did your organisation rely on:a.     In-house counselb.    External solicitors;c.     A firm of accountants;d.    License management specialistse.     Other consultantsf.     None of the above. 10.  What is:a.     The name of your CTO/CIO; andb.    The email address of your CTO/CIO?

column6: European Union Food Information for Consumers Regulation (EU FIC)
column7: From 13 December 2014, food businesses in the UK will have to follow new rules in labelling pre-packed foods and non-prepacked (loose) foods. This is part of the European Union Food Information for Consumers Regulation (EU FIC) coming into force.I am happy to receive your response by email.-                What press releases / announcements have you issued relating to these new rules?-                What publicity (including, but not limited to leaflets and emails) have you issued relating to these new rules?-                Please provide internal emails (from 1st Jan 2014 to date) detailing discussions regarding the implementation of these new rules?-                Please provide details of internal meetings (from 1st Jan 2014 to date) and discussions regarding the implementation of these new rules?-                Please provide internal emails (from 1st Jan 2014 to date) detailing publicity and the publicising of these new rules.-                What training has taken place for council staff in connection with enforcement of these new rules?-                Provide a copy of the enforcement policy for these new rules.-                What information have you sent to any of your own departments (including Social Services, Adult Services, Education) about these new rules?-                How many press releases have you issued relating to these new rules?-                How many press releases have you issued in total from September 1st 2013 to date?-                Please provide evidence of how local food businesses are supported and prepared for these new rules, including any internal communications to support evidence of this process.-                Please provide any internal emails or minutes from meetings to support the decision making process in the development of any food standards projects.

This request follows legal and mandatory legislation under the  European Performance of Buildings Directive and specifically T.M44  AirConditioning Assesment certification. Your AirConditioning  Assesment Certificates should be readily available at all times and  be lodged on the government Landmark database. Failure to have  appropriate Certificates will be subject to fines of £300 per  building, each week.Q. It is a legal requirement that you hold valid AirConditioning  Assesments if any building has a total of more than 12kw of air  conditioning present. Certificates are valid from 5 years of the  issue date. Have you undertaken a T.M44 AirConditioning Assesment? Q. Who is the responsible person for ensuring that your buildings  are surveyed and assessed, please provide the name, address, email  address and telephone number of the responsible person. Q. If your T.M44 Certificates are in place, what is their expiry  date? Q. What was the order value of the works placed with the Company  which undertook the work? Q. Provide a breakdown of the price per building if available. Q. How many Certificates were produced? Q. Was the Assessor independent as required under the Regulations? Q. Name the Assessor organisation. Q. Do you have ISO 14001 Accreditation

column7: I would like to request the following information under the Freedom of Information Act. For data requested for 2014-15 (so far) please provide information up to and including the 28th August 2014 or the nearest possible date.1.	Please list the number of requests for Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS) authorisations your local authority received from care homes and hospitals in the financial years 2012-13, 2013-14 and 2014-15 so far.2.	Please list the number of DoLS authorisation requests that were not carried out within statutory timescales (in most cases 7 days for urgent authorisations and 21 days for standard authorisations) in each of the financial years 2012-13, 2013-14 and 2014-15 so far.3.	Please list the number of applications your local authority made to the Court of Protection to authorise deprivation of liberty  in settings not covered by the DoLS (e.g. supported living) in 2012-13, 2013-14 and 2014-15 so far.4.	How many legal challenges to deprivations of liberty did your council receive in 2012-13, 2013-14 and 2014-15 (so far)?5.	How much has your local authority spent on independent Best Interests Assessors in 2012-13, 2013-14 and 2014-15 so far?Please also provide a copy of any action plan your council has drawn up in response to the implications of the 'Cheshire West' Supreme Court ruling on deprivation of liberty in March.My contact details are below should you require any assistance with any elements of this request.

How many ILF clients did you have when the Fund was closed to new applicants in 2010; and how many do you currently have?2.    What have been the main reasons for the decline (if applicable):a.    ILF users entering residential careb.    ILF users entering hospitalc.    Death of ILF users d.    Other (please outline here):3.    How many new users do you estimate would have qualified for ILF since 2010 in your local authority since 2010 had it not been closed to new applicants?4.    What analysis have you made of the impact on the disabled people (and their families, if applicable) who have been unable to access ILF since 2010?5.    How will your local authority ensure ILF users benefit from the 'transitional' funding planned from central government for the next financial year?6.    Does your authority intend to allocate funding for current ILF users beyond the transition year irrespective of government plans?  7.    What plans do you have for monitoring the impact of the closure of the ILF on current users in your local authority area? 8.    Do you think your local authority will be able to maintain funding ILF users to the same, lesser or greater degree as a result of government changes? a.    Our authority will have to significantly reduce support for existing ILF users b.    Our authority will have to reduce support for ILF users somewhatc.    Our authority will keep support for ILF users about the samed.    Our authority will somewhat increase support for ILF userse.    Our authority will significantly increase support for ILF users

1. What is your annual spending on services specifically for people (adults and children) exposed to domestic abuse in Devon County Council? Please supply for the following time periods: April 2011 March 2012, April 2012 March 2013, April 2013 March 2014. This should include, for example, spending on victim support, refuge provision, perpetrator programmes and services for children. The figures provided for question 1 should not include spending on primary prevention or universal education programmes. 2. How much of this spending was for services specifically directed at children exposed to domestic abuse through intimate partner violence between their parents or other significant adults in their lives. Services directed at children means domestic abuse services where children are identified the primary beneficiary. This could be a service that is delivered directly to a child, a linked service delivered to the child and a parent, or a service that is delivered to a parent with the explicit goal of improving outcomes for the child. The figures provided for question 2 should not include spending on any primary prevention programmes, universal education programmes or services which specifically respond to domestic abuse in young people s own relationships. 3. Following on from question 2, please provide a list of the services delivered in Devon which are directed at children exposed to domestic abuse through intimate partner violence between their parents or other significant adults in their life. Please provide a brief description of each service, including information on eligibility criteria. In particular, please state whether the service is available to children who are experiencing domestic abuse at the time of the intervention or whether it is a post-abuse recovery service. Please supply this information for the following time periods: April 2011-March 2012; April-2012-March 2013; April 2013-March 2014.

Dear FOI Team.  I would like to request the following information under the Freedom of Information Act.    I understand my request will take 20 working days to process but I would be grateful if you could acknowledge receipt via Christopher.hastings@mailonsunday.co.uk I note that the Freedom of Information Act carries a presumption in favour of disclosure. I also note that the Act guarantees access to copies of documents and not just the information contained within. 1....Does the council hold documentation which lists those schools which have applied for determinations so they no longer have to provide an act of worship which is broadly Christian in nature.2....If the answer to the above question is yes can you please state how many schools have applied for a determination since 1 January 2014.3....Can you please provide a full list of these schools together with their addresses.4...In the case of each school can you please provide the status of the application.  For example has the application been deferred?  Postponed?  Rejected? Approved?  Or is still pending? 5...In the case of each school can you please provide copies of all correspondence and communications including emails with the school which relates to this application.  This material will include but not be limited to proposals for alternative forms of worship and or assemblies. Please include all information irrespective of the decision regarding the application. 6...In the case of each school can the council please provide correspondence with its local SACRE which relates to the application.  Please do include all relevant supporting documents.  Please include all documents irrespective of the decision regarding the application or its current status? 7....Could the council please state how many schools have applied for determinations in each of the previous four years (2010,  2011, 2012, 2013).   For each of the aforementioned years can you please state how  many of these were successful. 8 ...Can the council state the total number of primary and or junior and or secondary  schools in its area which have either successfully applied for a determination or are not providing an assembly which is broadly Christian in nature.

column7: Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, I request Devon to provide me with the following information.1) How many schools are there in Devon with children eligible for the universal infant free school meal initiative?2) Were all of these schools in a position to offer a hot and nutritious meal at lunch time for these children at the start of this academic year? I am writing on behalf of Healthwatch England, the consumer champion for health and social care users in England. We would like to request answers for the following five questions under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. 1.	Under the reforms brought in by the Health and Social Act 2012, all upper tier local authorities were given responsibility for commissioning an Independent Complaints Advocacy Service for local NHS services. Please can you tell us how much money you spent / allocated  for this service for the following financial years - 2013/14 and 2014/15?2.	Can you tell me how many individuals have been supported in making their NHS complaint by the Independent Complaints Advocacy Service in your area for the following financial years - 2013/14 and 2014/15 (to date if available)?  3.	In addition to complaints advocacy for NHS services, does your local authority directly provide or commission complaints advocacy services for those looking to make complaints or raise concerns about local social care services?4.	If you do provide or commission complaints advocacy services for social care users, how much money have you spent on / allocated for the service for each of the following financial years - 2013/14 and 2014/15?5.	If you do provide or commission complaints advocacy services for social care users, how many individuals have been supported for each of the following financial years - 2013/14 and 2014/15 (to date if available)?Under the Act I understand that we are entitled to a response within 20 working days of your receipt of this request (which I estimate to be Monday 6 October). I am happy to receive a response to my request in parts if some questions are easier to answer than others. Under the terms of the FOI Act, I also request details of any redactions of exemptions applied. I would prefer to receive the information electronically, sent via email to enquiries@healthwatch.co.uk under the subject: 'Healthwatch England FOI - Social Care Complaints Advocacy Services'.Please acknowledge receipt of this request. Please also contact me if you require any clarification around this request.

Good afternoon,Please see below for a request for info from Torbay council. I have been told that this request should be dealt with by you so I have been asked to forward to you.Kind regards,Kieran Pawley Service Support Assistant (MASH & CP Checks) Business Strategy and Support Services  Address: Multi Agency Safeguarding Hub, PO BOX 723, Exeter, EX1 9QSTel: 01392 383000MASH Enquiries: 0345 155 1071 Email: kieran.pawley@devon.gcsx.gov.uk Website: www.devon.gov.uk Disclaimer: www.devon.gov.uk/email.shtml 'Building Stronger Support'Please note that emails may be disclosed in response to requests under the Data Protection Act 1998 and Freedom of Information Act 2000. From: Durtnall, Lynsey [mailto:Lynsey.Durtnall@torbay.gcsx.gov.uk] Sent: 01 September 2014 11:48To: Child Protection Checks Secure - Mailbox; 'Childprotect@plymouth.gcsx.gov.uk'; 'MultiAgencyReferralUnit@cornwall.gcsx.gov.uk'; 'child.protection@brighton-hove.gcsx.gov.uk'; 'ChildCare.Duty@BATHNES.GCSX.GOV.UK'; 'safeguardingunit@dorsetcc.gcsx.gov.uk'; 'duty.intake@n-somerset.gcsx.gov.uk'Subject: RESTRICTED: Request for InformationHello,Firstly apologies if this email has been sent to the incorrect person. Current number of children subject to Child Protection Plans under the category of Sexual Abuse 2.	Current total number of children subject to Child Protection Plans (not including any temporary CP Plans) Thank you very much for your assistance and apologies again if this has been sent to the incorrect person.Regards, Lynsey DurtnallSenior Business Support OfficerSafeguarding and Reviewing Service1st Floor, 87 Abbey Road, Torquay, TQ2 5NNPost c/o Town Hall, Castle Circus, Torquay, TQ1 3DR Tel: 01803 208567Fax: 01803 208565Email: lynsey.durtnall@torbay.gov.uk Secure Email: lynsey.durtnall@torbay.gcsx.gov.uk

column7: Please would you provide me with the following data as an FOI request.How many different types of bins are provided to your residents for different types of waste collection, e.g. recyclying, food waste, general waste, etc.?How often are each of them collected?Do you have any ancillary charges for collection, e.g. for garden waste? If so, how much and what for?How much have you gained in revenue through charges, rather than tax, in each of the past three years from householders for waste collection of any kind?

Following the new decision by the Government to close the ILF  (Independent Living Fund) on June 30th 2015 and devolve funding to  Local Authorities, please could you answer the following  questions.1: Will monies transferred from the closure of the ILF to your  local authority be ring fenced to ILF recipients in your area? If  no decision has yet been taken, what is the process and timescale  for this happening?2: Please could you state the process and timescale for meeting  with current ILF recipients to prepare personal care plans for 1st  July 2015 onwards (bearing in mind the assessments at the Transfer  Review visits only indicate desired outcomes and do not produce an  actual care package).3: Will you be making any special dispensation for allowing ILF  users to continue to employ their current & in many cases long  standing carers of many years, bearing in mind some may be paid a  higher rate than what LA's may usually advise and be family  members  too?

column7: To whom it may concern,I am making this request under the Freedom of Information Act 2000.  I am gathering information on bus and public transport provision in Devon as part of our Save the Buses campaign, which maps cuts to bus services across the country.  We know that the Government have made deep cuts to local authority budgets, and that this is having an effect on the provision of local bus services.  We would like to gather a national picture of bus cuts, so that we can explain to central Government exactly how their decisions are having an impact across the country.My questions are as follows:1. What is Devon County Council's total budget for supported bus services in 2014/15?2. What was Devon County Council's total budget for supported bus services in 2013/14?3. What was Devon County Council's total budget for supported bus services in 2012/13?4. What was Devon County Council's total budget for supported bus services in 2011/12?5. What was Devon County Council's total budget for supported bus services in 2010/11?6. What is the budget for supported bus services as a percentage of the total transport budget? (For the purposes of this request 'transport' includes highway maintenance, home to school/college transport; adult social care transport; demand responsive transport; special educational need transport and voluntary driver schemes, cycling and walking, roads spending, supported bus services and fares).7. How many and which supported routes have had cuts in services in the fiscal year 2014/15 (for example loss of weekend or evening services)?8. How many and which supported routes have been completely withdrawn in the fiscal year 2014/15?9. What changes have been made to non-statutory concessionary fare schemes in the fiscal year 2014/15?Yours faithfully,Martin AbramsCampaign For Better Transport-------------------------------------------------------------------

I would like to make a Freedom of Information request to discover the following:1: The number of children your council has in care 2: The number of children your council has in care who have same mother3: The number of children who have between one and two siblings also in care4: The number of children who have between three and four siblings also in care5: The number of children who have between five and six siblings also in care6: The number of children who have more than seven siblings also in careIf these questions exceed the costs limits, then please advise me how to reduce my questions to stay within the limits. I definitely want the answers to Q1 & Q2 - but I am willing to condense Qs 3-6 into larger groupings if necessary.Thank you, Amelia Hill
column8: Some information sent but part exempt

column7: I'm afraid to say it looks like something off of Play School and is a gross departure from the existing site.  Whilst I appreciate you need to make things clear, please not at the expense of people's intelligence - it is patronising and demeaning.  Please save DCC some money and leave the current as it is - if it ain't broke don't fix it.  The money would be better spent on weed spraying or the like where it is really needed.Whilst writing please can you confirm under Freedom of Information how much this development has cost to date.RegardsPeter DunnWe're making changes to the Devon County Council website to make it easier to use. We've already updated our adult health and social care pages and we're now working on our roads and transport pages.You are regular users of our site and important customers so we need your feedback to make these pages work effectively. We've developed a draft site to test out the new 'report a problem' pages. https://beta.devon.gov.uk/roadandtransport/ Could you test how the pages look and work for reporting faults such as potholes, overgrown vegetation or broken streetlamps. We need to know:1.      is the site clear and attractive?2.      can you see what you need to do and where you need to go?3.      does the functionality work - can you make a report easily, does everything make sense?4.      does the site work on mobile devices such as tablets and smart phones?5.      is there something missing?  Is there something we should be doing differently?If there is any other feedback you have about the pages we'd love to hear it. If you could send replies by Thursday 18 September that would be helpful, but we're happy to get feedback at any time.This is a draft site so it's still under construction; many of the sections are incomplete and you may find parts of the site change from day to day. If you have any questions please email or phone me.

Under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, The Vitamin D Mission would kindly request the following information:                    1.         As part of your responsibility to deliver a local health and wellbeing strategy, can you tell us whether you have a programme to address vitamin D deficiency and raise awareness amongst groups at higher risk and those who care for them in the case of infants and young children under 5 years?Please answer: Yes/NoIf Yes:-     What is your approach to increase the availability and uptake of vitamin D supplements and improve awareness of the importance of vitamin D amongst at-risk groups and those who care for them in the case of infants and young children under 5 years? -     Which health and social care professionals are responsible for implementing vitamin D awareness and at-risk prevention programme?  2.         Guidance was issued by the four UK Chief Medical Officers in February 2012 recommending:"All infants and young children aged 6 months to 5 years should take a daily supplement containing vitamin D in the form of vitamin drops, to help them meet the requirement set for this age group of 7-8.5 micrograms of vitamin D per day. However, those infants who are fed infant formula will not need vitamin drops until they are receiving less than 500ml of infant formula a day, as these products are fortified with vitamin D. Breastfed infants may need to receive drops containing vitamin D from one month of age if their mother has not taken vitamin supplements throughout pregnancy."Are you aware of this advice and have you acted upon the CMO recommendation?Please answer: Yes/NoIf Yes:-     Based on the above CMO advice, what have you done to ensure vitamin D supplements are widely available for all at-risk groups including infants and children under 5 years?-     What plans do you have in place to ensure health and social care professionals in contact with at-risk groups including infants and children under 5 years are made aware of the following: a)         local policies and procedures in relation to vitamin D b)         local sources of vitamin D supplements c)         local sources of Healthy Start supplementsd)         Are you monitoring uptake of Healthy Start supplements?Please answer Yes/NoIf Yes:1.	What is the uptake of free vitamin D supplements for infants and children who are eligible for the Government's Healthy Start scheme?If No:2.	What future plans do you have to monitor uptake of vitamin D supplements?3.         Do you currently conduct a vitamin D awareness programme?Please answer Yes/NoIf Yes:1.	What plans do you have in place to ensure messages and information about the importance of vitamin D for good health, are disseminated locally to groups at higher risk, and those who care for them in the case of infants and young children under 5 years? This includes addressing any misconceptions parents may have about the risk of vitamin D insufficiency among infants and children and sources of vitamin D in the UK (from safe sun exposure, supplements and limited dietary sources) If No:-     What are the barriers to implementing your local vitamin D awareness programme e.g. budget/knowledge of at-risk groups and solutions/other public health priorities/health and social care professionals' training, other (please state)?4.         Are you aware of the draft guidance published by NICE in May 2014: Vitamin D: Implementation of Existing Guidance to Prevent Deficiency?Please answer Yes/No

column6: Underage pregnancies in Devon Care Homes
column7: My original request to Mr Garry Streeter M P was for his help in the Freedom of Information Actregarding how many underage girls became pregnant in the care of Devon Social Services while living in their Care Homes before the Social Services started closing them. The M P Garry Streeter and I have corresponded with letters and Email and his advice was now to request this information myself. My daughter has been the victim of abuse while in the care of Devon Social Services at a Totnes Care Home. This information was given to the court on 19th September 2013. There was no interest shown by the Social Services regarding this information at Court on the Thursday or on Friday 20th September 2013. There was no professional curiosity by the Advanced Social Worker Abbey Rowland or the solicitor at the time so I went to the police over the weekend following  Court. This is now part of ongoing complaints procedures Stage 2 with the Ombudsman being involved as I have not excepted this and other upheld complaints. My daughters information regarding her historical care is very disturbing and that is the reason for my request. The first direct contact by the Social Services with my daughter over this abuse was on the 28th July 2014 when they asked her by telephone if she wanted to talk to them about it. Does that say something about their interest in serious historical sexual child abuse?  Can you please give me this information under the Freedom of Information Act as it is relevant to my daughters circumstances while she was in the care of Devon Social Services at the time of her historical abuse.

column7: This is a request for information, filed under the Freedom of information act 2000. We wish to obtain the information, from the Council, relating to unclaimed business rate credit balances. We are aware that all Billing Authorities hold on account sums of money that are due to be returned to ratepayers and for a variety of reasons have not been repaid and maybe considered untraceable by the Council.  We therefore request a breakdown of credit balances accrued since your earliest records, for the amounts owing to all incorporated companies within the authorities billing area, including-          The name of each business in respect of which non-domestic rate credit balances remain payable-          The value of overpayment in each case which remains unclaimed-          The years(s) in which overpayment was made and-          The hereditament address-          The name of each business in respect of which non-domestic rate credit balances has been written back on to the ndr account-          The value of write back in each case which remains unclaimed-          The years(s) in which write back was made (if available) and-          The hereditament address that the write back relates to

column6: Communications between Town/Parish Councils and DCC
column7: Dear Karen Vallois,I think the most relevant department is Highways as they are the department that control the things that there are most complaints about e.g. road maintenance, verge cutting, highway signs, drain clearing, on street parking, parking restrictions, speed limits the list goes on.Regards,Marc Cornelius From: access to information - mailbox [mailto:accesstoinformation-mailbox@devon.gov.uk] Sent: 12 September 2014 15:28To: Marc CorneliusSubject: RE: Freedom of Information Request: Communications Between Town/Parish Councils and DCCDear MarcThank you for your e-mail.However, to enable us to refer your query to the relevant department, please provide us with further information.Please advise if you are referring to a particular type of service, e.g. Highways, Social Care.We look forward to hearing from you.Karen ValloisInformation Governance AssistantFrom: Marc Cornelius [mailto:marc.cornelius@vercor.net] Sent: 11 September 2014 10:36To: access to information - mailboxSubject: Freedom of Information Request: Communications Between Town/Parish Councils and DCCQuite simply:1.       How are town/parish clerks advised to communicate with Devon County Council? 2.       Are they given contact details of the relevant DCC officers?3.       If the answer to Question 2 is No: a.       Why are they not given these details?b.      Who made this decision?I would prefer a response by email.Marc CorneliusCrown HillAlswear New RoadSouth MoltonEX36 4BBTel: 01769 572336Fax: 01769 599660

column6: Annual spend on public health areas
column7: I'm writing to request statistics for the following:The separate annual spend on each of these public health areas:Sexual Health,Drug misuse - adults,Alcohol misuse,Smoking,Obesity,Physical activity.I am requesting the spend for each of the public health concerns in the spending year 2014/15.Where the spend is spread across multiple brackets through schemes or initiatives which will, for example, focus on obesity and physical activity, please apportion the correct amount of funding that has gone to each sector's outcomes. Where this is not possible, please spread the cost evenly over each appropriate category.

column6: Total spending on alcohol and drug treatment services for 2013/14 and the budget for 2014/15
column7: Please send me:1/ The total spending on alcohol and drug treatment services under Public Health Expenditure within your authority for the years 2013/14 and the budget for 2014/15.  Also indicate if any other department are providing funding and if so how much.   Please divide your response between:Drug misuse - adultsAlcohol misuse - adultsDrugs and alcohol youth serviceIf your contracts combine drug and alcohol services, please provide the expenditure and indicate that it is for both alcohol and drugs treatment.2/ If you have forward funding plans for alcohol and drug treatment services over the following 3 years (2015/16, 2016/17, and 2017/18) can you include that data as well.Please exclude funding for alcohol/drugs education.

I would like to know the following:- 	Can you state, for each year, how many occasions the council has invoked the powers of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act during the financial years of 2011/2012, 2012/2013 and 2013/14.- 	For each instance of the powers being invoked can you provide a brief description of the the reason for invoking the RIPA powers.- 	For each instance of the powers being invoked can you state the outcome. E.g. whether a conviction was secured, a penalty notice issued or no further action was taken.I would like to receive the information in electronic format, preferably in an Excel document.

1. Within your local authority, and for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 what was the number of 16-17 year olds who:a) presented themselves as homeless or at risk of homelessness directly to your children's servicesb) were referred to your local authority's children's services by one of your district councils because a 16 or 17 year old had presented themselves as homeless or at risk of homelessness.2. Within your local authority, and for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 what was the number of 16-17 year olds who presented themselves as homeless or at risk of homelessness either to your children's services or referred to you by district councilsand:a) were assessed by your local authority children's services?b) were assessed jointly by your local authority children's services and the housing services of your district council?3. Within your local authority, and for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 what was the number of 16-17 at risk of homelessness assessed either by your local authority children's services or jointly with the housing services of your district councils, who were:a) assessed as not being children in need of support under the Children Act 1989 and reunited with their family/ carersb) assessed as children in need under section 17 of the Children Act 1989 but were not offered accommodationc) were assessed as not in need of support under the Children Act 1989 and offered accommodation under the Housing Act 1996 by the relevant housing authorityd) were assessed as children in need of support under section 20 of the Children Act 1989 and offered accommodation as looked after children4. Within your local authority, for the years 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, how many 16-17y.o. and care leavers aged 18-20 were housed in:a) supported accommodationb) returned to live with parents or other family members (that may include moving-in withpartners)c) hostelsd) Bed and Breakfastse) Private rented accommodationf)  Local Authority accommodationg) Registered provider, such as a housing association.h) university accommodation or accommodation connected to an educational establishmenti) not knownj) staying put arrangements5.These questions are all about council policies and support services:a) Do you provide specialist advocacy support for 16 and 17 year olds who presentthemselves as homeless and, if so, what organisations do you commission to provide thissupport?b) A 16-17 year old, presenting as homeless, or at risk of homelessness, who has beenassessed as a child in need under section 20 of the Children Act 1989 but refuses tobecome a looked after child?c) What support does your local authority offer to c1) 16-17 year olds, c2) 18-20 year oldcare leavers to furnish accommodation provided by your council.d) What is the policy of your local authority when 16-17 year old who were assessed as notowed a housing duty present themselves repeatedly as homeless or at risk ofhomelessness?e) What is the policy of your local authority when 18-20 year old care leavers who areeligible for accommodation from housing services but get evicted due to e1) behaviour or e2)rent arrearsf) What is the policy of your local authority when 16-17 year olds who are eligible foraccommodation from housing services but get evicted due to f1) behaviour or f2) rentarrears?g) Please provide your most recent policy statement stating how your local authorityassesses homelessness in 16 and 17 year olds.

column6: Complaint CS903864 - Traffic Management Plan for Sidmouth Folk Festival
column7: Sally Richardson,Thank you for the time you have had to put into this case so far.I have yet to respond formally by way of appeal to the Tribunal or to update my website.In the interim, I now seek disclosure by DCC at this later date. You indicated in your formal response that this might be possible 'at a later date' once the 'commercial confidentiality' phase of any ongoing discussions had passed. According to Press reports a week or more ago, the organisers (Sidmouth FolkWeek) no longer aim to try and use this new site in the next few years (if ever). Therefore there seems no remaining genuine reason for not disclosing a document that would shed light on the performance of your highways staff in advising EDDC.In particular there is no further 'commercial confidentiality' or predjudice to ongoing negotiations, since these have effectively ceased owing principally to local hostility and widespread recognition of the traffic/highways problems and dangers that use of the proposed venue would have caused. These were obvious to many folk festival attendees even if they were not to either your staff or the festival organisers. There was some considerable open discussion on the internet of course.I have discussed the site and its problems with the National Trust who are the owners of the land. They are not expecting any further application. Key factors considered by the ICO in their determination have therefore now substantially changed.

column6: School transportation on the basis of medical status
column7: In the previous (April 2013/14) and present year, how many pupils/ students have been successful at receiving funding for transportation to/from school/ college on the basis of medical status. These are individual's deemed to be in need of transport to prevent walking or other arrangements unsuitable due to medical/ developmental circumstances. I should like this broken down according to area and type of medical condition if possible.In the previous and current year, how many pupils/ students (or their care-givers) have been required to provide additional evidence of medical need for transport over a GP letter or GP signed form. I would like this broken down according to month or year. I should also like to know the type of additional evidence such as report from hospital consultant, physiotherapist etc.I would like copies of all policies and procedures held by DCC on processing applications for medical transportation to/ from school related to the past two years. This should include any documents that outline the protocols for assessing medical evidence for  award determinations related to school transport.

column6: Responsibility for the cost of long term nursing care
column7: The late Mrs Doris Edwards DOB: 01/04/1914DOD: 29/09/2008NHS continuing healthcareWe are instructed by Mr Raymond Edwards on behalf of the late Mrs Edwards's estate.We have been instructed to investigate whether the long term nursing care needs of the late Mrs Edwards met the eligibility criteria for NHS Funded Continuing Health Care and whether Torbay and Southern Devon Health and Care should have been responsible for the cost of Mrs Edwards's healthcare fees.In order to advise our Client fully in this matter, we would be grateful if you would please kindly provide us with copies of all social services records, assessments and care plans in relation to the late Mrs Edwards.

I am seeking the following information about the council's allocations policy for applicants to the council's social housing register. Could you send me this information:1) The length of the council's housing register/social housing waiting list (number of households)2) The number of council homes in the borough's housing stock3) The number of housing association homes in the borough's housing stock4) The number of social housing allocations made each year since 2010. 5) The number of years people must live in the borough to be eligible to join the housing register6) The council's criteria for priority bandsCould you send me the council's complete preference criteria for Band A housing register applicantsBand B housing register applicantsBand C housing register applicantsBand D housing register applicantsCould you also tell me:7) How does the council determine priority between applicants who meet reasonable preference criteria in each band?8) Does the council prioritise social housing applications from people who are employed over people who are unemployed?9) Does the council and/or the borough's housing associations have council or social housing homes, builds or estates that exclude people who are unemployed?10) Does the council prioritise social housing applications from serving or ex-members of the armed forces?11) Does the council prioritise social housing applications from people who are engaged in voluntary or community work or activities?12) Does the council prioritise social housing applications from people who have caring duties?13) Are there any other categories of applicants that the council gives social housing selection priority to/ are there any other means by which applicants can improve their priority for housing?14) Please also send me a complete copy of your housing application policy.

column6: Loss of personal data by the council and breaches of security involving personal data held by t...
column7: I am requesting under the Freedom of Information Act, information about loss of personal data by the council and breaches of security involving personal data held by the council.I would like to know:A) All incidents in the past 24 months where personal data held by the council had been lost, stolen, or the security protecting personal data held by the council had been breachedB) The date these incidents occurredC) Details of what data were lost, stolen or had its security breached, including the number of people whose personal data were involvedD) An estimate of the cost of losing the data, including any fines incurred for losing dataE) What measures the council took to protect privacy as a result of the incidentIf the decision is made to withhold some of this information using exemptions in the Data Protection Act, please inform me of that fact, cite the exemptions used in each case, and provide me with all the requested information that is not withheld.If some parts of this request are easier to answer than others, I would ask that you release the available information as soon as possible.

column6: Road surface of Dorset Avenue, Exeter
column7: I am extremely concerned about the state of repair of Dorset Avenue in Exeter.The road appears to be a concrete base which I understand was covered somewhle ago with tarmac Can you confirm:Q1) Was the road surface of Dorset Avenue originally concrete?Q2) When was Dorset Avenue covered with tarmac?Q3) is there a specified depth a road be covered in tarmac in such circumstances?It is my unerstanding that safety inspections should be carried out in accordance with the Code of Good Practice for Highway Maintenance Management, published by the Institute of Highways and Transportation. I understand that he recommendation is interpreted that local roads should be inspected every 3 to 6 months, and all other roads (such as local access roads) should be inspected at least annually. These inspections should be carried out on foot and a written report of all defects should be maintained.I cannot believe that these inspections and reports do not show Dorset Avenue to be in serious need of repair.Q4) Is Dorset Avenue classified as a locval access road?Q5) When Dorset Avenue was last inspected?Q6) What were the  recommendations arising from that inspection. Q7) What action should be taken as a result of those recommendations?Q8) Is there any timescale to implement those recommendations

column6: Issue of licenses for Hackney and Private Hire taxis
column7: Public Sector FOI Request: We are making a request under the freedom of information act 2000.This request specifically relates solely to the issue of licensing for Hackney and Private Hire drivers   1.	Please provide a fully copy of your current policy and procedure to approve / appoint / issue a hackney or private hire badge. 2.	Please confirm the current number of Hire drivers currently approved for; a.	Hackney Hireb.	Private Hirec.	Private Ambulanced.	Others 3.	Please confirm current number of licence applications received; a.	Number of new Hackney & Private Hire licence applications annually for the past three years, or for the period of a licence usually issued.b.	Number of new Hackney & Private Hire licence applications granted for the past three years, or for the period of a licence usually issuedc.	Number of new Hackney & Private Hire licence renewed annually for the past three years, or for the period of a licence usually issued 4.	Please confirm the precise method of checking a driving licence for all approved badge holders. a.	Physical inspection of Counterpart and Photocard i.	Do you have a plan in place for when the DVLA stop issuing Counterparts in 2015 b.	Please confirm if you require the licenced holder to provide evidence of his/her driving licence being checked using a DVLA service i.	Use of consent for D796 personallyii.	Use telephone conference service c.	Please confirm if you submit D796 in the name of the Local Authority direct to DVLA and receive a data subject disclosure document. d.	Please confirm if you use a third party organisation registered with DVLA EDECS service. e.	Please confirm if you use a service other than those described in c or d above. 5.	How frequently is a badge holder driving licence checked or rechecked? a.	Annuallyb.	Biannuallyc.	At renewal of badged.	Other frequency periods, if so please state. 6.	At what level of conviction(s) or penalty points would a badge holder be revoked? 7.	Is the cost of initial and further DVLA licence checks or rechecks passed on to the badge holder, shared costs or paid in full by the authority? 8.	Do you currently use a 'licence system' such as IDOX Lalpac, Uniform, Diamond service or similar a.	Please provide the name of the service provider and service usedb.	Does this service include driving licence checking servicesc.	If no to b. would it benefit the authority if a driving licence checking service was to be included within this type of solution, assuming the cost benefits where acceptable?

I would like to make a request under the Freedom of Information Act 2000 about the funding of Early Education Entitlement - often known as Early Years provision for 3 and 4 year-olds.  1.     Please can you tell me if your council provides Free Early Education Entitlement to four year-olds once they have started in a reception class at school or does this funding allocation stop once they leave nursery and start formal education? 2.     If it does continue once school starts, is this money paid directly to the state school until the term after the child in question turns 5 (the cut-off age for the entitlement) or can a parents use the money to pay an accredited childminder for extra help e.g to do school pick up if they have a job? 3.     Equally, if the child is instead at a private (independent/ fee-paying school) is the money paid to that school until the term after the child turns five? Does this only happen if that school had a nursery attached?  4.   If yes to question 3, do you know how many independent/private/fee-paying schools have nurseries attached to them in your region?  If question 4 would require more time than is allocated under FOI, I would be happy to only have a response to the first three.
Please see attachment on Request document

column6: Deaths of people with no known next of kin from 1/6/14
column7: THIS REQUEST IS FOR COUNTY, BOROUGH & UNITARY COUNCILS AND DOES NOT RELATE TO PUBLIC HEALTH FUNERALS PER SE. IF THE CASE WAS PASSED TO A 3RD PARTY FOR A PUBLIC HEALTH ACT FUNERAL TO BE CARRIED OUT, THEN PLEASE PROVIDE DETAILS OF THE CASE AS PER THE QUESTIONS BELOW. THANKS!I would like to know details of anyone who has been under the care of the County Council Guardianship/Deputyship Team* who has died with no known next of kin from 1/6/2014 to the day of your reply. *The Guardianship Team is known by different names at different County Councils, for example: Client Affairs, Protection Team, Adult Care Team, Deputyship Team, Appointeeship Team or other similar name.Please include:1.	 the deceased's full name(s)2.	the date they died3.	the approximate value of their estate(s)4.	their dates of birth or age at death whether or not they were married, divorced, single, or widowed 5.	the maiden surnames of married females or widows 6.	their  address at death7.	the date when a referral was made of this estate to the Treasury Solicitor or Duchy of Lancaster or Cornwall or any other 3rd party to research or administer and the name of the 3rd party concerned8.	if a referral to the Treasury Solicitor or Duchy has not yet been made and you think it will be made soon could you advise me of this too.9.	if a case is still  undecided or awaiting referral, please also advise of details.

column6: Disabled people and deprivation of liberty
column7: 1. Since the 19th March 2014 Supreme Court judgement how many new supported living placements have you made?2. How many of these placements had, as required by law, a formal assessment of the person's mental capacity by a mental health or best interests assessor? - the answer would be expected to be 100% to comply with law 3. How many of the people placed into supported living were determined to not have mental capacity to consent to being in supported living 4. How many of the people assessed as not having mental capacity to consent to being in supported living were also assessed as under continuous supervision and control and not free to leave?5. How many Court of Protection applications have been made to ensure the proposed deprivation of liberty is legal.6. For those cases that should be taken to but have not been taken to the Court of Protection (before or after the Consolidated Court Case hearing at the Court of Protection on 5th and 6th June 2014 In Re X and others (Court of Protection Guidance; Deprivation of Liberty Cases) -[2014] EWCOP 25; [2014]WLR (D) 376 Ct of Protection; Sir James Munby P) what was the rationale for not taking them and when do you intend to come into compliance with the law?7. How many of the placements you have made into supported living without an application to the court of protection but that may require such an application do you believe could be subject to legal challenge?Of the Supported Living placements made before the Supreme Court Judgement8. How are you dealing with the placements and reviewing them to ensure they are in compliance with the new judgement 9. Of the supported living placements made before the Supreme Court judgement : how many havea) Already been reviewedb) Are in the plan to be reviewed so that they are compliant with the requirements of the Supreme Court judgementc) How many Court of Protection applications have you made for these existing placements to legalise the deprivation of libertyd) How many further Court of Protection application are expected to be made and what is the time line

As of today, the Connecting Devon & Somerset website, (http://www.connectingdevonandsomerset.co.uk/further-information/omr-request/ ) makes the statement: "In order to secure this funding, we have matched it with an additional £19.167M from Local Authority partners".  The funding referred to is an allocation of £22.75M made to Connecting Devon & Somerset by BDUK in February 2014, for the Superfast Extension Programme which BDUK require to be matched locally, £1 for £1. My request is for:(a) A breakdown by Local Authority of how the £19.167M is made up.(b) For each Local Authority (or any other body) that is contributing to the £19.167M match funding, which ones have irrevocably committed the amounts they are contributing and which ones are yet to confirm their commitment, subject to approval by their Full Council, their Cabinet, their Chief Executive or other properly constituted body within that Local Authority.

column7: Are housing applicants that approach the council for urgent re-housing because they are at immediate risk of harm due to domestic violence required to declare themselves homeless by applying through the Part 7 homelessness route in order to be re-housed under the council's housing allocations scheme?Are housing applicants that are suffering domestic violence given reasonable preference under the council's housing allocations scheme?Are housing applicants that are suffering domestic violence given additional preference under the council's housing allocations scheme?Are housing applicants that are suffering domestic violence placed in the top priority Band in the council's housing allocations scheme? If not which Band are they placed in?If a points scheme is in operation how many points are applicants who are suffering domestic violence awarded? Is this the highest award of points within the housing allocations scheme? If not what priority will the points give these applicants within the allocations scheme?Are housing applicants that are suffering domestic violence made direct offers by the council?Are housing applicants that are suffering or at risk of severe life-threatening domestic violence prioritised as 'Exceptional Cases'?Which Band(s) are housing applicants placed in if they are considered to be homeless under S166A (3)(a) and have an urgent need to move because of domestic violence? Are any of these the top priority Band?Do current council tenants who are accepted as homeless because of domestic violence retain their tenancy rights if they are placed in temporary or emergency accommodation?Are housing applicants who are suffering domestic violence given the same priority within the allocations scheme regardless of tenure?

Local authorities that have oversight with regard to education receive a grant from the government known as the Direct Schools Grant (DSG). The vast majority of the monies received are sent directly to schools. However, the DSG rules specify that some monies can be held back for central services. One of these could be the employment of teachers to offer advice and support to schools that have children on the autistic spectrum, the teachers of such children and the parents of such children. I would be grateful for the number of qualified teachers that you employ centrally who provide support in autism. I would be grateful if you would provide me with information that could be fractional, for example a teacher may be on a half-time contract or might have functions outside autism that takes up half their time and hence you would report this as 0.5.
